    Recent Developments in the Biology and Medicinal Chemistry of CDK9 Inhibitors: An Update

    • Tizhi Wu
      Tizhi Wu
      Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Drug Design and Optimization, Department of Medicinal Chemistry, School of Pharmacy, China Pharmaceutical University, Nanjing 210009, People’s Republic of China

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Cyclin-dependent kinase 9 (CDK9), which regulates transcriptional elongation, is an attractive therapeutic target for many cancers, especially for cancers driven by transcriptional dysregulation. In particular, CDK9 promotes RNA polymerase II pause/release, a rate-limiting step in normal transcriptional regulation that is frequently dysregulated in cancers. Emerging evidence indicates that selective CDK9 inhibition or degradation may provide a therapeutic benefit against certain cancers. Indeed, the development of CDK9 modulators (inhibitors and degraders) has attracted great attention, with several molecules currently under clinical development. This review provides an overview of recent advances in CDK9 modulators in general, with special emphasis on compounds under clinical evaluation and new emerging strategies, such as proteolysis targeting chimeras (PROTACs).

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Today, cancer remains one of the leading causes of death and a serious threat to human health worldwide.(1) From the microscopic point of view, the unlimited abnormal proliferation of cells is the main feature of tumorigenesis and development.(2) In multicellular organisms, cell proliferation and differentiation are regulated by the cell cycle.(3) Dysregulation of the cell cycle and increased resistance to apoptosis are the main causes of tumors.(4) As members of the serine/threonine kinase family, cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs) are major drivers of cell cycle regulation mechanisms, promoting DNA synthesis and mitosis by phosphorylation of key substrates.(4,5) The abnormal activation of CDKs promotes dysregulation of the cell cycle and uncontrolled proliferation of cells, leading to the development of malignant cancer.(6) Accordingly, targeting CDKs has been considered as an effective strategy for developing anticancer drugs.(7−9)
    The biological activity of CDKs is tightly associated with another family of regulatory proteins called cyclins.(10) They bind together to form functional heterodimeric complexes responsible for the regulation of various cellular vital functions, including proliferation, differentiation, apoptosis, and DNA damage repair.(11) While CDKs levels remain constant throughout the cell cycle, the levels of cyclins vary according to the protein synthesis and proteasome degradation rates, ensuring that CDKs are not activated until needed.(11) Depending on their function, CDKs are divided into cell cycle CDKs (including CDK1, CDK2, CDK4, CDK6) and transcriptional CDKs (including CDK7–9, CDK11–13, CDK19) (Table 1). Cell cycle CDKs play significant roles in the synchronization of cell cycle progression, while transcriptional CDKs are mainly involved in mechanisms of transcriptional regulation (Figure 1).(6) Recently, the recognition of transcriptional addiction as a potential vulnerability in various cancer types has led to an increasing interest in transcriptional CDKs.(12) As a key activator in transcriptional regulation, CDK9 has attracted special attention from medicinal chemists.(12)
    Table 1. Biological Functions of Representative CDKs and Their Corresponding Cyclins
    classificationCDKacyclinfunctions
    cell cycle CDKsCDK1cyclins A and Bregulate G2 and M phase and control entry into mitosis(13)
    CDK2cyclins A and Ephosphorylate RBb, activate transcription factors E2F, and govern DNA replication(14)
    CDK3cyclin Cphosphorylate RB and regulate G1 phase(15)
    CDK4/6cyclin Dmediate the phosphorylation and inactivation of RB and regulate entry into the S phase(16)
    CDK5cyclin Dregulate neuronal process, promote angiogenesis, and increase expression of cyclins and other CDKs(17)
    transcriptional CDKsCDK7cyclin Hregulate the initiation and elongation of transcription and activate CDKs(18)
    CDK8cyclin Ca subunit of the mediator complex that functions as a transcriptional regulator(19)
    CDK9cyclins T and Kpromote transcription elongation(20)
    CDK11cyclins L1 and L2play significant roles in mRNA transcription, mitosis, and cell apoptosis(21)
    CDK12cyclin Kphosphorylate the CTDc of RNA polymerase II and regulate mRNA processing(22)
    CDK13cyclin Kregulate mRNA processing and gene expression(21)
    CDK19cyclin Ccontrol mediator structure and function and phosphorylate transcription factors(23)
    a

    CDKs, cyclin-dependent kinases.

    b

    RB, retinoblastoma proteins.

    c

    CTD, C-terminal repeat domain.

    CDK9 specifically regulates gene transcription elongation and mRNA (mRNA) maturation.(20) When CDK9 was first isolated, it was designated as PITALRE for its characteristic amino acid motif (Pro-Ile-Thr-Ala-Leu-Arg-Glu).(24) Subsequently, a study of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) confirmed that CDK9 was a significant component of the positive transcription elongation factor b (P-TEFb) complex that phosphorylates the carboxyl-terminal domain (CTD) of RNA polymerase II (RNAPII)(25) Many studies have demonstrated that a dysregulated CDK9 signaling system is prominent in a variety of hematologic malignancies and solid tumor cell lines, and CDK9 inhibition can result in growth inhibition and apoptosis in cancer cells.(26,27) Therefore, targeting CDK9 is an appealing strategy for treating cancers, and an increasing number of researchers are devoted to the development of CDK9 inhibitors. However, most CDK9 inhibitors, especially those in clinical development, are broad-spectrum inhibitors due to the highly conserved structure of CDKs,(28) which may result in unpredictable side effects.(29,30) Several CDK9 inhibitors have already been halted from clinical studies due to serious side effects, which may be associated with their poor selectivity (e.g., roniciclib).(31,32) Thus, the improvement of the selectivity of CDK9 inhibitors may be beneficial to patients.(24) In this review, we provide an overview of the biological and structural characteristics of CDK9 and describe its main functions in various cancers. Additionally, our attention is mainly focused on the discussion of design strategies for the development of selective CDK9 inhibitors by studying the discovery process of representative CDK9 modulators reported in recent years from the perspective of medicinal chemistry. It should be noted that this review does not discuss in detail those inhibitors that have been discussed in detail in a previous review.(33)

    2. The Biology of CDK9 and Its Role in Cancer

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    2.1. The Biology of CDK9

    The gene encoding human CDK9 is located near the telomeric end of the long arm of chromosome 9 at position q34.1.(34) The two different promoters present in the CDK9 gene lead to the generation of two CDK9 isoforms, one is the best characterized short form 42 kDa protein (CDK942) originally identified as PITALRE, and the other is the less characterized long-form 55 kDa protein (CDK955).(20) Compared to CDK942, CDK955 has an additional 117 amino acid residues at the N terminus.(34) The protein levels of the two isoforms are different, and CDK942 is more highly expressed in cells. In addition, both exhibit differences in subcellular localization, regulation, and tissue distribution.(35) CDK942 is mainly distributed in the cytoplasm and nucleus, and CDK955 is mainly found in the nucleolar region.(24) Studies have demonstrated that CDK942 participates in global transcriptional regulation, while CDK955 is mainly involved in DNA repair and genome integrity through different functions.(36) It is worth noting that more expression and function patterns of CDK955 are still not fully explored, while CDK942 is currently the most studied and main driver of transcription.(37)
    In vivo, the formation of the CDK9–cyclin (including cyclinT1, T2a, T2b, and K) complex and the phosphorylation of the key Thr186 residue is required for the activation of CDK9.(33) In addition, bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) and CDK7 are reported to regulate CDK9 activity.(38) As a part of P-TEFb, CDK9 stimulates transcriptional elongation by the phosphorylation of the RNAPII CTD, which consists of a 7-amino acid tandem repeat.(39) In order to promote the transcriptional elongation, CTD needs to be hyperphosphorylated.(24) Ser2 and Ser5 are the main phosphorylation sites for CDK9 and CDK7, respectively.(40) The phosphorylation of Ser5 by CDK7 activates RNAPII, thereby stimulating the transcription of RNA. The transition into the productive elongation phase results from the phosphorylation of Ser2 by the CDK9–cyclin complex.(40,41)
    CDK9 precisely regulates the elongation of RNA transcription (Figure 2).(24,41) After being released from the preinitiation complex, RNAPII starts elongating but pauses at the promoter-proximal region due to the effect of the negative elongation factors (NELF) and DRB-sensitivity inducing factor (DSIF), which also blocks the initiation of new RNAPII molecules.(35) In the presence of BRD4, the CDK9–cyclin T complex is recruited to the promoter region, phosphorylating DISF, NELF, and the Ser2 of RNAPII CTD. The phosphorylation causes the release of the NELF complex and converts DISF into a positive factor, leading to the removal of elongation blocks. Then, RNAPII begins transitioning into the elongation phase and also stimulates the initiation of new RNAPII molecules.(35)

    2.2. The Role of CDK9 in Cancer

    CDK9 plays a significant role in the regulation of global transcription, especially in the transcription of the apoptosis regulator myeloid cell leukemia 1 (Mcl-1) and the downstream protooncogene MYC involved in cell growth and cell cycle progression, which control proliferation and survival of tumor cells.(42,43) As a result, the dysregulation of CDK9 signaling is prominent in various cancer cells, including hematological malignancies and solid tumors (Table 2). Mechanistically, CDK9 inhibition blocks phosphorylation at Ser2 of the RNAPII CTD and induces downregulation of MYC as well as Mcl-1 protein levels, which were confirmed in various hematological malignancies, including adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATL),(44) acute myeloid leukemia (AML),(45) chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL),(46) multiple myeloma (MM),(47) and natural killer (NK) cell leukemias/lymphomas.(48) It has been reported that the selective CDK9 inhibitor BAY-1143572 significantly decreased ATL tumor infiltration in the liver and bone marrow of treated mice, suggesting that selective CDK9 inhibitors may have the potential to treat ATL.(44) The successful use of CDK9 inhibitors in the treatment of solid tumors has also been reported for prostate cancer,(42) gastric cancer,(49) ovarian cancer,(26) and human head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC).(39) In addition, high expression of CDK9 was observed in chordoma cell lines and chordoma tissue.(50) Both CDK9 inhibition and silencing resulted in the growth inhibition of chordoma cells, suggesting that CDK9 represents an emerging potential target in chordoma therapy.(50,51) Importantly, recent research demonstrated that CDK9 inhibition reactivated epigenetically silenced genes in cancer, leading to the restoration of tumor suppressor gene expression, cell differentiation, and activation of endogenous retrovirus genes.(28) All of these studies suggest that CDK9 is a promising therapeutical target in cancer treatment.
    Table 2. Main CDK9-Related Effects or Mechanisms in Various Cancer
    tissuecancerCDK9-related effects or mechanismsref
    liverhepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)Inhibition of CDK9 is able to induce cell apoptosis in HCC cell lines.(52)
    lungnonsmall-cell lung cancer (NSCLC)Inhibition of CDK9 results in the suppression of cell cycle progression, colony formation, as well as cell proliferation and induces apoptosis in NSCLC lines. Additionally, because CDK9 inhibition leads to reduced mRNA and the protein levels of cFlipa as well as Mcl-1, the CDK9 inhibitor combined with TRAIb can potently kill cells in a panel of mostly TRAIL-resistant NSCLC lines.(53,54)
    stomachgastric cancerMicroRNA-613 with protein levels obviously reduced in gastric cancer tissue and cells is able to repress proliferation and migration of gastric cancer by inhibiting CDK9 expression.(49)
    breasttriple-negative breast cancer (TNBC)Inhibition of CDK9 reduces the levels of cyclin B1 and MYC in TNBC cell lines.(55)
    ovaryovarian cancerInhibition of CDK9 significantly decreases cell growth and viability by suppressing the phosphorylation of RNAPII and inducing apoptosis in ovarian cancer cells.(26)
    prostateprostate cancerSer81 phosphorylation by CDK9 is a core event in the regulation of AR, which controls the nuclear retention, chromatin binding, transactivation of specific gene expression, and transcriptional activity of AR. Overexpression of CDK9–cyclinT leads to an increased Ser81 phosphorylation in cells.(42)
    bloodmultiple myeloma (MM)Inhibition of CDK9 significantly induces cell apoptosis and suppresses the transcription of antiapoptotic protein Mcl-1 in MM cells.(48)
     acute myeloid leukemia (AML)Overexpression of CDK9 promotes the cell proliferation of antiapoptotic protein Mcl-1, which is necessary for the survival and sustained growth of AML cells. In addition, the inhibition of CDK9 can result in apoptosis of AML cells.(45)
     adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATL)In ATL, inhibition of CDK9 results in the suppression of phosphorylation at Ser2 of the RNAPII CTD and induces downregulation of c-Myc as well as Mcl-1 protein levels.(44)
     chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)In CLL, inhibition of CDK9 results in the suppression of phosphorylation of RNAPII and inhibition of RNA synthesis and induces downregulation of Mcl-1 and X-linked inhibitor of apoptosis protein levels.(46,56)
     natural killer (NK) cell leukemias/lymphomasIn NK-cell leukemias/lymphomas, the selective CDK9 inhibitor is able to prevent the phosphorylation of Ser2 of the CTD in RNAPII, which brings about downregulation of c-Myc and Mcl-1 protein levels, promoting growth inhibition and apoptosis of NK-cell leukemias/lymphomas.(48)
    lymphaggressive MYC-driven B cell lymphomaInhibition of CDK9 suppresses Mcl-1 to induce durable apoptotic responses in aggressive MYC-driven B cell lymphoma.(57)
    head and neckhuman head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC)In HNSCC cells, CDK9 overexpression leads to radioprotection, while CDK9 depletion obviously enhanced the radiosensitivity of HNSCC cells.(39)
    coloncolorectal cancerCDK9 inhibitors show significant cytotoxicity in HCT116 and HT29 cells and promote depolarization of mitochondrial membrane, resulting in caspase-independent apoptosis.(58)
    bonechordomaInhibition of CDK9 significantly suppresses cell growth and proliferation in chordoma cell lines.(50)
    neuroneuroblastomaBlocking the activity of CDK2 and CDK9 results in potent antiproliferative effect and induce cell death in a panel of neuroblastoma cell lines.(59)
    a

    cFlip, cellular FLICE-like inhibitory protein.

    b

    TRAIL, tumor necrosis factor-related apoptosis-inducing ligand.

    3. CDK9 Inhibitors in Clinical Evaluation for Cancer Therapy

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    To our knowledge, 16 CDK9 inhibitors have been or are currently being in various stages of clinical development for cancer treatment (Table 3).(60) Among them, four inhibitors, namely, P-276–00 (3), ZK-304709 (5), BAY-1000394 (6) and SNS-032 (13), have been discontinued, while others, including Alvocidib (1), TP-1287 (2), P-1446 (4), BAY-1143572 (7), BAY-1251152 (8), TG-02 (9), (R)-Roscovitine (10), Fadraciclib (11), Dinaciclib (12), AT7519 (14), BTX-A51 (15), and AZD-4573 (16), are active in various clinical trials.(60) These compounds can be mainly divided into two categories according to their structures, namely, flavones and base analogues (such as aminopyrimidine, aminopyridine, and a nitrogen-containing fused heterocycle). Among the flavone derivatives, compound 3 has advanced into phase III trials (the last phase of the trials), while the other three are still in early phase clinical trials, i.e., 1 in phase II, 2 in phase I, and 4 in phase I (Table 2). The other compounds are all in phase I or phase II. Although most of these inhibitors (1–6 and 9–15) show potent but nonselective inhibition of CDK9 enzymatic activity, with IC50 values in the nM range.(60) Several of them have been confirmed to have potent antitumor activity by targeting CDK9, such as compounds 1, 3, and 9 (see sections 4.2.1 and 4.2.2). However, due to the lack of selectivity, most nonselective CDK9 inhibitors may result in adverse effects, which limit their further clinical application in cancer treatment.(24) In a phase II study of compound 1 for patients with CLL, 100% of patients suffered from side effects, and 87% were at high risk.(61) Due to adverse effects, such as nausea and vomiting, compound 5 was prematurely discontinued in a phase I study for patients with advanced solid tumors.(62) A phase Ib/II study of compound 6 combined with chemotherapy in patients with extensive-disease small-cell lung cancer showed the promising efficacy of the compound.(63) However, 42 patients (97.7%) suffered from side effects, such as nausea and vomiting, and 16.3% of the patients experienced serious adverse events. Due to its unacceptable adverse effects, the phase II study of compound 6 was discontinued.(63) The multitargeted CDK inhibitor 12 was involved in three-phase II clinical studies in which more than 75% of the patients had adverse effects, although the compound exhibited single-agent potency in patients suffering from multiple myeloma.(64−67) The enrollment in a phase I study of compound 13, a potent inhibitor targeting CDK 2, 7, and 9, was terminated due to toxicity problems during dose escalation. All patients in this study suffered from side effects, including fatigue, nausea, diarrhea, and abdominal pain.(68) Besides adverse effects, many CDK9 inhibitors showed no clear objective responses in patients. No complete response was observed in more than half of 12 phase I studies of compound 1 and three phase II trials of compound 12.(24,65−67) Although the drug level in the expected therapeutic range was achieved and target engagement was confirmed, there was no objective response in the treatment of AML with compound 8,(69) a selective CDK9 inhibitor which is currently in an active clinical trial.(60) Overall, clinical trials for the treatment with various CDK9 inhibitors have revealed many detrimental effects, and most of them remain unsuccessful. Improvement in the selectivity and antitumor activity of CDK9 inhibitors can lead to the availability of a successful treatment for cancer patients.
    Table 3. CDK9 Inhibitors That Have Been or Are Currently Being Tested in Clinical Trials
    a

    The IC50 values were achieved through a kinase-based assay.

    b

    The information is from the web of Clarivate Analytics Integrity (https://integrity.clarivate.com).

    4. Design Strategies and Structural Types of CDK9 Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Due to the essential role of CDK9 in cancers, considerable medicinal chemistry efforts have been devoted to the design of highly potent CDK9 inhibitors. Among these inhibitors, several have been or are currently being evaluated in various clinical trials. Recently, an increasing amount of medicinal chemistry effort is focused on the development of novel CDK9 inhibitors with diverse structural scaffolds to achieve better selectivity, higher potency, and superior safety profile.

    4.1. Structural Features and Binding Sites in CDK9

    CDK family members share high sequence and structural similarity. Among them, CDK9 is similar in structure to CDK2, and both share 40% sequence identity,(70) which makes it challenging to design selective CDK9 inhibitors. Structurally, like other kinases, CDK9 is composed of a C-terminal lobe, mainly containing α-helixes, and a smaller N-terminal lobe, mainly comprised of β-sheet and one α-helix. The N-terminal lobe comprises the residues 16–108, while the C-terminal lobe comprises the residues 109–330 of the CDK9 protein.(34,70)
    Functional domains of CDK9 mainly include a glycine-rich G loop, an αC-helix, and a hinge in the N-terminal, as well as an activation loop and a catalytic loop in the C-terminal (Figure 3). The glycine-rich G loop comprising the consensus sequence GXGXXGXV is capable of interacting with triphosphate chain, while the αC-helix is the main region where CDK9 combines with its cyclin partners, such as cyclin T and K.(34) The hinge is a key region of the CDK9 binding sites. The hydrogen bonds between ligands and the hinge residue Asp104, as well as Cys106, in the CDK9 protein, are essential for the ligand activity (Figure 3). For example, the core scaffold of CDK9 inhibitors in clinical trials forms hydrogen bonds with the residues in the hinge region, which significantly contribute to their CDK9 potency (Figure 4).(34) The activation loop (T loop) is the location of a threonine residue whose phosphorylation is essential for the enzymatic activity, which in CDK9 is Thr186. In addition, the residues Asp149, Lys151, and Thr191 of CDK9 form the catalytic loop, which directly participates in the transphosphorylation reaction.(34) Notably, some less conserved regions in CDK9 binding sites, including the hydrophobic region, the solvent-exposed region, may provide an opportunity to design selective CDK9 inhibitors.(24)

    4.2. CDK9 Nonselective Inhibitors

    Most CDK9 inhibitors have poor selectivity over other CDKs due to the high homology of these proteins in the catalytic domain. Structurally, CDK9 nonselective inhibitors can be divided into three categories based on the group binding with the hinge residues, namely flavonoids, aminopyrimidine, and nitrogen-containing fused heterocycle compounds.

    4.2.1. CDK9 Inhibitors Bearing the Flavonoid Scaffold

    Flavopiridol (1), a synthetic flavonoid from a plant native to Indian, was developed for the potential treatment of cancer.(71) As the first CDK inhibitor entering clinical studies, compound 1 is a potent CDK inhibitor with broad specificity for most CDK family members, including CDK1, CDK2, CDK4, CDK5, and CDK9 (IC50 = 20, 15, 19, 14, and 3 nM, respectively).(71) In fact, compound 1 showed maximum suppression of CDK9 and interfered with RNAPII activation and associated transcription.(71) Some studies reported that 1 exhibited anti-inflammatory via CDK9 and NFκB-dependent signaling,(72) and CDK9 was the most relevant target of compound 1.(73,74) The crystal structure of 1-CDK9 revealed the formation of hydrogen bonds from the 4-O oxygen and 5-O hydroxyl of compound 1 to hinge residues Cys106 and Asp104 in CDK9, respectively. Additionally, the 3-O hydroxyl of 1 interacts with Asp167 (Figure 5A) and this interaction contributes to its potent inhibitory effect on CDK9 kinase activity. The compound 1 can potently induce apoptosis of CLL cells in vitro and is effective for the treatment of liver cancer, breast cancer as well as prostate cancer. Indeed, it has already been approved as an orphan drug for CLL.(75) Since this drug binds avidly to plasma proteins, higher serum concentrations were required for clinical antileukemia activity than those suggested by in vitro studies, leading to significant toxicity, including high rates of major tumor lysis syndrome, cytokine release syndrome and secretory diarrhea.(76) However, a new clinical study of flavopiridol and venetoclax in patients with relapsed/refractory AML is being conducted and is currently in the recruitment stage.(77)
    The water solubility of compound 1 is poor under neutral or basic conditions (both 0.02 mg/mL at pH 6.8 and pH 8.7), hampering the development of the oral formulation. Thus, a phosphate prodrug TP-1287 (2) was designed and synthesized to improve solubility and oral bioavailability (Figure 5B).(78) The prodrug 2 was shown to have a good water solubility (9.5 mg/mL at pH 6.8 and 9.3 mg/mL at pH 8.7), displaying high oral bioavailability (%F = 182.3, compared to intravenous 1) with an efficient conversion to the parent compound 1 in mouse pharmacokinetic (PK) studies. Furthermore, 2 achieved excellent antitumor efficacy in a xenograft model, exhibiting 109.1% tumor growth inhibition at a dose of 7.5 mg/kg. This orally delivered CDK9 inhibitor 2 has recently advanced into clinical trials for the treatment of solid tumors.(60)
    Bharate et al. designed a series of flavonoid derivatives based on compound 1, with the aim of improving oral bioavailability.(79) After several rounds of structure–activity relationship (SAR) discussions, the replacement of the chlorophenyl group in 1 with a 2,6-dichlorostyryl group led to compound IIIM-290 (17), which displays excellent potency against CDK9 (IC50 = 1.9 nM), strong cellular antiproliferation activity in leukemia cells (GI50 = 0.5 and 0.9 μM for MOLT-4 and HL60 cell lines, respectively) and potent growth inhibition of tumors in pancreatic, colon, and leukemia xenograft nude mouse models (Figure 5B). In addition, 17 exhibited good physicochemical and PK properties (water solubility = 20.31 μg/mL, Log P = 3.09, Cl = 55.4 mL/min/kg, oral bioavailability = 70.7%). However, 17 lacked selectivity over other CDKs, especially CDK2 (IC50 = 16 nM).(79)
    Recently, Nada Ibrahim et al. reported the discovery of a new series of compound 1 analogues targeting CDK9 by introducing sugars, amino acids, and heterocycle groups on the ring C of compound 1.(80) Cell viability assays of ovarian cancer lines demonstrated that the analogues bearing sugars or amino acids displayed poor cytotoxic activity, while the derivatives containing heterocycle potently inhibited tumor cell growth with submicromolar IC50 values. Among them, compound 18, containing benzimidazole, exhibited the best antiproliferative activity and showed high cytotoxic potency in seven tumor cell lines (including ovarian cancer, gastric adenocarcinoma, breast cancer, prostate cancer, pancreatic cancer, colon carcinoma, and leukemia cell lines) with six of seven IC50 values being within 100 nM, which are comparable to those of compound 1. However, 18 displayed slightly reduced inhibitory activity against CDK9, and the CDK9 selectivity was still not good enough (IC50 = 64, 1725, and 1093 nM for CDK9, CDK2, and CDK5, respectively).(80)
    Rearrangement of the six-membered piperidine of flavopiridol to a five-membered ring pyrrolidine resulted in the clinical pan-CDK inhibitor P-276–00 (3). The compound turned out to be more selective for CDK4, CDK1, and CDK9 with IC50s < 100 nM, and less selective for non-CDK kinases.(81) However, studies have shown that CDK9 is the major target of compound 3 in multiple myeloma cells.(47) In addition, in vitro studies have shown that the antiproliferation and pro-apoptotic activity of compound 3 in human lung, colon, breast, and leukemia cell lines was at least two times higher than that of 1. Unfortunately, a phase II study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of 3 in mantle cell lymphoma was terminated due to a lack of objective responses.(82) The introduction of a trifluoromethyl group at the para position of the benzene ring in compound 3 led to another clinical CDK inhibitor, namely, voruciclib (4), with higher potency against CDK9, CDK4, and CDK6 (IC50 = 1.68, 3.96, and 2.92 nM, respectively) as well as less non-CDK off-target liability than 1 (Figure 5B).(83) Compound 4 could significantly induce apoptosis in various tumor cells, such as chronic lymphocytic leukemia cells, nonsmall-cell lung cancer cells, and human colon cancer cells.(84) Meanwhile, recent studies demonstrated that 4 was capable of potentiating the potency of paclitaxel and doxorubicin in cells overexpressing ATP-binding cassette transporters. These transporters are major obstacles impeding the effect of cancer chemotherapy. Thus, 4 has a potential application prospect in combination with antitumor drugs for cancer chemotherapy and is currently in phase I clinical study (recruitment phase).(85)
    Wogonin (19) is a natural product isolated from the plant Scutellaria baicalensis, and its structure is similar to that of compound 1. The natural product has been shown to be a potent CDK9 inhibitor (IC50 = 190 nM).(86) However, its activity and selectivity against CDK9 need to be further improved. Our group recently disclosed a series of wogonin derivatives to investigate the effect of substituents at the 8-methoxy group and B ring of 19 on the CDK9 activity and selectivity by structure-based drug design (Figure 6).(87) In order to evaluate the effect on its selectivity for CDK9, different electron-withdrawing or -donating groups were introduced into the B ring of 19, which led to compound 20 with significant improvement in the selectivity against CDK9 over CDK2. With the aim of improving the enzymatic potency, different polar and nonpolar groups were introduced into the O8 of compound 20. Among them, compound 21 was a potent CDK9 inhibitor with an IC50 value of 19.9 nM, and showed a 45-fold selectivity over CDK2 (IC50 = 913 nM), demonstrating a clearly improved CDK9 inhibitory activity and selectivity compared to compound 19. The cellular antiproliferative studies suggested that compound 21 had potent antiproliferative activity against a panel of 14 tumor cell lines, preferentially against MV4–11 (IC50 = 20 nM), but displayed low toxicity against normal cell lines (IC50 = 15 and 22 μM for HEK293 and L02, respectively).(87)
    Molecular docking studies were performed to understand the interaction pattern of the representative compound 21 in the active site of CDK9 (Figure 7). The carbonyl group of 21 forms a hydrogen bond with Cys106 in the hinge region, while the NH group of the O8-pyrazole ring forms another important hydrogen bond with Ala153 (Figure 7A), which contribute to the high CDK9 inhibitory activity of 21. In addition, we found that the steric hindrance of Lys89 at the inlet of the ATP-binding pocket made it difficult for 21 to adopt a stable conformation and bind tightly to CDK2 (Figure 7B). The corresponding amino acid in CDK9 is Gly112, which is more favorable for accommodating the piperazinyl group of 21 and results in good selectivity versus CDK2.(87)

    4.2.2. CDK9 Inhibitors Bearing the Aminopyrimidine Scaffold

    The structure-based optimization of pyrimidine-based inhibitors resulted in the clinical candidate TG02 (9, Table 3 and Figure 4), a potent inhibitor of CDKs, Janus kinase 2 (JAK2), and Fms-like tyrosine kinase-3 (FLT3).(88) Although compound 9 is a pan-CDK inhibitor, CDK9 is considered as a primary target of this compound, which potently inhibited CDK9 with an IC50 value of 3 nM.(89) Notably, the macrocyclic scaffold of 9 is rare among all CDK inhibitors, especially CDK9 inhibitors. The macrocycle, with a basic nitrogen in 9, forms a salt bridge with the Asp86 in CDKs, which contributes to its high potency.(88) Researchers have suggested that macrocyclization is essential to present the pharmacophore elements in the required conformation for binding to the protein by lowering the conformational energy penalty.(88) Compound 9 could inhibit the growth of various cancers, including AML (IC50 = 18–39 nM), colon carcinoma (IC50 = 40–305 nM), prostate carcinoma (IC50 = 43–84 nM), breast carcinoma (IC50 = 65–164 nM), lung carcinoma (IC50 = 110 nM), nonsmall-cell lung cancer (IC50 = 242–258 nM), and small-cell lung cancer (IC50 = 95–139 nM).(60) Research has demonstrated that the antitumor activity of 9 in the AML is mediated by the dephosphorylation of RNAPII leading to depletion of survival molecules, such as Mcl-1 and XIAP, with subsequent activation of BAX, culminating in apoptosis.(90) Given its excellent antitumor activity and drug-like properties, 9 progressed into clinical development for advanced leukemias and multiple myeloma in 2010. Currently, there are three ongoing clinical studies of 9, at the moment in the recruiting phase, for a brain tumor, glioblastoma, and high-grade gliomas, respectively.(77)
    Recently, Wang et al. disclosed the synthesis and biological evaluation of a series of 5-chloro-pyrimidine-2,4-diamine derivatives that exhibited potent inhibition of CDK9, culminating in the discovery of 28, a novel dual CDK6 and 9 inhibitor.(91) The enzymatic activity screening in the in-house compound library led to the hit 22 with a pyrimidine diamine core. Hit 22 showed moderate inhibitory effects on CDK6 and CDK9 but bound more tightly to CDK2 (IC50 = 6.65, 3.43, and 0.03 μM, respectively). With the aim of improving the potency against CDK6/9 and selectivity over CDK2, a series of pyrimidine diamine derivatives were designed and synthesized starting from hit 22 through structure-based drug design.
    The docking study of 22 was first performed to analyze its key interactions with CDK6/9. Two hydrogen bonds were formed between 2-amino pyrimidine and key residues (Val101 and Cys106 in CDK6/9, respectively). In addition, the o-methyl phenyl moiety of 22 occupied the hydrophobic pockets in the CDK6/9 (Figure 8). According to the docking results, the structural optimization was performed step by step. First, the replacement of the pyridine ring of 22 with various phenyl, substituted phenyl, and other heterocycles produced compound 23 with slightly improved potency. Subsequently, the detailed SAR studies were conducted to evaluate the effects of the N position, the distance between the pyridine and pyrimidine, and the substitution of the pyridine ring on the enzymatic potency, culminating in the discovery of compound 24 bearing N-methylpiperazine. Compared to compound 23, compound 24 exhibited much better potency for CDK6/9 and selectivity over CDK2. Unfortunately, the change of length between the phenyl and pyrimidine groups proved to be disappointing. Then, the authors undertook to explore the influence of the substitution of the phenyl ring to improve the enzyme inhibitory activity. Although the incorporation of bulk hydrophobic groups resulted in higher CDK6 inhibitory activity, the affinity of most compounds for CDK9 decreased significantly (25, 26, and 27). The extensive SAR study eventually led to compound 28 with an acetylamino group at the meta position of the phenyl (Figure 8). Compared to compound 24, compound 28 exhibited improved CDK9 potency and a balancing effect on CDK6/9, as well as slight inhibition of CDK3/5/11 at 1 μM, suggesting its good preference for CDK6/9. The acetylamino group in 28 was considered to interact with key residues in the hydrophilic region of CDK6/9 (Lys43 and Asp163 in CDK6; Lys48 and Asp167 in CDK9), which contributed to an increase of the activity against CDK6/9 100-fold higher than that of compound 22.(91)

    4.2.3. CDK9 Inhibitors Bearing the Nitrogen-Containing Fused Heterocycle Scaffold

    Variolins (29, IC50 < 0.04 and 0.21 μM for CDK9 and CDK2, respectively) and meriolins (30, both IC50 < 10 μM for CDK9 and CDK2) are natural products with CDK inhibitory activity, including against CDK9 and CDK2.(92,93) Hybridizing the structure of these two compounds generated a 3-pyrimidinylazaindole derivative (31, IC50 < 0.03 μM for CDK9 and CDK2), with better activity against CDK9 and CDK2. Furthermore, this derivative exhibited an antiproliferative activity in tumor cell lines and significant growth inhibition in a mouse LS174T (colorectal carcinoma) xenograft cancer model.(94) However, compound 31 had poor physicochemical and PK properties, limiting its further clinical applications. Recently, Umed et al. reported the synthesis and biological evaluation of a new generation of analogues with a 3-pyrimidinylazaindole scaffold.(95) Binding-mode analysis of 31-CDK2 and 31-CDK9 complexes revealed that 7-azaindole was the key pharmacophore as the moiety formed two hydrogen bonds with the hinge residues Cys106 and Asp104 in CDK9 (Leu83 and Glu81 in CDK2) (Figure 9). The introduction of hydrogen bond acceptors, hydrogen bond donors, or hydrophobic groups was feasible for the substitution at the 5-positions of ring A and the amino group of ring C. Thus, extensive structural modifications were carried out at these two moieties to improve the physicochemical and PK properties while retaining the potency for CDK2 and CDK9, culminating in the discovery of the potent CDK9 and CDK2 inhibitor 32 (Figure 9). In vivo assays suggested that 32 strongly inhibited CDK9 and CDK2 with IC50 values of 24 nM and 5.5 nM, respectively, and displayed high inhibition of cell proliferation in HCT-116 (IC50 = 0.2 μM) and SH-SY5Y cells (IC50 = 0.8 μM). After the treatment with 32 in mouse triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), a significant tumor growth inhibition (90%) was observed, indicating its potential to be a development candidate against TNBC.(95)
    In 2018, Li et al.(96) disclosed the identification of compound 35 (IC50 = 12 nM for CDK9), derived from the hybridization of ribociclib (34) and vorinostat (33), which was a histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitor (Figure 10A). In addition to CDK9, 35 showed significant inhibitory activity against CDK4 (IC50 = 8.8 nM) and HDAC (IC50 = 12 nM). It is worth noting that this compound displayed a clearly enhanced suppression against CDK9 compared to ribociclib (IC50 = 197 nM for CDK9). The docking model revealed that a new hydrogen bond was formed between 35 and residue Thr29 of CDK9 (Figure 10 B). In addition, treatment with 35 in the 4T1 model with an oral dose of 90 mg/kg, a higher tumor growth inhibition was observed compared to vorinostat and ribociclib at the same dose, suggesting that compound 35 can generate excellent tumor regression in vivo.
    In 2019, Wang et al. described a series of novel, highly potent, and selective CDK9 inhibitors with inhibitory activity against cancer stem cells (CSCs).(53) Similar to the study by Li et al.,(96) they designed various merged molecules by combining the pyrrolo-[2,3-d] pyrimidines-2-amine in 34 with isothiocyanate from sulforaphane (36), which is a known natural compound targeting CSCs and can potently inhibit tumorigenesis and metastatic progression (Figure 10A). Compound 37 (IC50 = 11, 148, and 145 nM for CDK9, 4, and 6, respectively) is a representative example of these merged molecules, exhibiting selectivity over other CDKs and suppressing tumor growth.
    Compound 39 is also a hybrid derivative from 34 and cabozantinib (38), which is a vascular endothelial growth factor 2 inhibitor (Figure 10A).(97) Compound 39 was reported to potently inhibit CDK9 with an IC50 value of 12 nM and exhibited high selectivity over other CDKs. Moreover, it effectively induced apoptosis in cancer cells, such as breast cancer and lung cancer cell lines. Noteworthy, compared to 34 (IC50 = 197 and 13 nM for CDK9 and CDK4, respectively), 39 showed significant improvement in selectivity against CDK9 over CDK4 (IC50 = 12 and 142 nM for CDK9 and CDK4, respectively). The docking model revealed a new hydrogen bond between the Asn116 residue in CDK9 and the 4-(3-fluorobenzyloxy) group of 39, compared to the positive control 34 (Figure 10C).

    4.3. Efforts on the Development of Selective CDK9 Modulators

    In recent years, medicinal chemists have gradually turned their attention to the development of selective CDK9 inhibitors. Among the selective CDK9 inhibitors, three of them have progressed into clinical trials, including BAY-1143572 (7), BAY-1251152 (8), and AZD-4573 (16) (Table 1 and Figure 4). Furthermore, it is important to mention that the proteolysis targeting chimeras (PROTACs) strategy has been used to design selective CDK9 small molecule degraders. This technology could promote further understanding of the mechanism of CDK9 in tumorigenesis and development.

    4.3.1. Selective CDK9 Inhibitors Bearing the Aminopyridine (or Aminotriazine) Scaffold

    BAY-985 (40) bearing an N-triazine core was found to be a potent and highly selective CDK9 inhibitor (CDK9, IC50 = 11 nM; other CDKs, IC50 > 1078 nM) and exhibited good antiproliferative activity in HeLa cells (IC50 = 1 μM) and MOLM-13 cells (IC50 = 280 nM).(98) However, the unfavorable physicochemical and DMPK (drug metabolism and pharmacokinetic) properties of 40, such as low water solubility of 11 mg/L at pH6.5, short half-life (t1/2 = 0.7 h), and low bioavailability of 10%, limited the further development of this compound.(98) The docking experiment was performed to investigate the binding mode of 40-CDK9 (Figure 11A) revealed two hydrogen bonds formed between the hinge region of CDK9 and the triazine core, as well as the aniline NH, respectively. The benzyl sulfonamide moiety interacted with Glu107 and was directed toward the exit of the ATP-binding pocket. The benzyl sulfonamide group was believed to significantly contribute to the low water solubility of 40 due to its polarity, high number of heteroatoms, and multiple hydrogen-bonding interactions. Thus, efforts were focused on the modification of the benzyl sulfonamide group to improve solubility while maintaining good potency. A series of sulfone groups were used to replace the benzyl sulfonamide, resulting in compound 41 (IC50 = 24 and 1608 nM for CDK9 and CDK2, respectively). It exhibited similar potency against CDK9 and selectivity over CDK2 compared with 40 (IC50 = 11 and 1078 nM for CDK9 and CDK2, respectively). Notably, both compounds 42 (IC50 = 49 and 588 nM for CDK9 and CDK2, respectively), in which an additional methylene group was introduced to 41, and compound 43 (IC50 = 32 and 608 nM for CDK9 and CDK2, respectively), in which the methylene group from 41 was removed, displayed a clear reduction of selectivity over CDK2 and activity against CDK9.
    However, it was disappointing that 41 showed a lower water solubility of 4 mg/L compared to 40. A rather steep SAR about CDK9 selectivity and activity was observed when the structure on the right side of 40 was modified. Ultimately, the introduction of the uncommon benzyl sulfoximine group into 40 led to the discovery of compound 7. Compared with 40, compound 7 clearly exhibited a better overall profile in vitro and in vivo, similar inhibitory activity against CDK9 (IC50 = 6 nM), and higher selectivity (other CDKs, IC50 > 890 nM). The kinase selectivity assay demonstrated that only the GSK3 enzyme displayed submicromolar inhibition of non-CDK kinases with the treatment of compound 7 (IC50 = 45–87 nM). More importantly, 7 displayed a good water solubility of 479 mg/L, low blood clearance, and a moderate bioavailability of 54% in rats in vivo (Figure 11A). In in vivo efficacy studies, 7 could significantly inhibit the growth of MOLM-13 and MV4–11 tumor xenografts and promote almost complete tumor remission at a dose of 12 mg/kg for 14 days in an MV4–11 leukemia mouse model. Due to the promising overall profile, 7 was selected as a candidate compound to enter a clinical trial for advanced cancer and leukemia.(98)
    In order to fully investigate future treatment options using selective CDK9 inhibitors based on compound 7, extensive lead optimization efforts were made to find the novel CDK9 inhibitor 8.(99) Compared to 7, compound 8 exhibited improved enzymatic activity (IC50 = 3 nM against CDK9) and cytotoxic activity (IC50 = 29 nM against MOLM13 cells), increased selectivity over CDK2, as well as high permeability. Compound 8 was shown to potently suppress tumor growth in xenograft models and turned out to be another CDK9 inhibitor with high selectivity in the clinical development study. Unfortunately, more information about the discovery of 8 was not disclosed.
    AZ-5576 (44), a potent, highly selective, and orally bioavailable CDK9 inhibitor, has an aminopyridine scaffold. This compound inhibited CDK9 protein activity with IC50 values < 5 nM and suppressed Ser2-phosphorylation of RNAPII in cells with an IC50 of 96 nM.(100) A rapid dose-dependent decrease in pSer2-RNAPII with concomitant loss of Mcl-1 mRNA protein was observed after short-term treatment with 44 of the MV4–11 cell lines, which led to the cleavage and activation of caspase 3, as well as a decrease in cell viability. This compound could inhibit the growth of human leukemia cells with an IC50 of 50–100 nM. Further structure-based drug optimization was performed based on the scaffold of compound 44 to improve its physicochemical and PK properties suitable for an intravenous agent with short target engagement, which ultimately resulted in the identification of 16.(101) Compound 16 showed potent inhibitory activity against CDK9 (IC50 < 3 nM) with high selectivity over other CDKs (CDK1 = 370 nM, CDK2 > 10 μM, CDK4 > 10 μM, CDK7 = 1.1 μM) (Figure 11B). Kinase selectivity profiling demonstrated that 16 had a 100-fold higher selectivity for CDK9 compared to 8 of 14 top kinases. Compound 16 had a 25-fold higher cellular selectivity over other CDKs in the MCF7 cells, while exhibiting rapid induction of apoptosis broadly across hematologic cancer cell lines (GI50 = 23 nM). Short-term treatment with 16 led to the depletion of Mcl-1 in a dose- and time-dependent manner, which was considered as the mechanism of 16-induced tumor cell death.(101) Compound 16 had good water solubility suitable for intravenous administration. The half-life of 16 was less than 1 h in rat, dog, and monkey. A tolerated dose-dependent response was observed in the MV4–11 tumor xenografts after weekly treatment of 5 or 15 mg/kg of 16, dosed IP BID q2h on consecutive days. Moreover, the 15 mg/kg dose led to tumor regression in all mice, which lasted for more than 125 days. In addition, the combination of 16 and venetoclax achieved highly durable regression in all treated animals; the latter is a BCL2 inhibitor approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration (U.S. FDA) for treatment of CLL.(102) Therefore, as a selective CDK9 inhibitor, 16 was advanced into a clinical trial for the treatment of hematological malignancies. Unfortunately, the specific discovery process of 16 was not disclosed.
    The pyrimidine analogue 45 could potently inhibit CDK9 with an 80-fold higher selectivity versus CDK2 (Ki = 7 and 568 nM for CDK9 and CDK2, respectively).(103) Two cocrystal structures of 45 bound to CDK9 (PDB ID: 4BCG) as well as CDK2 (PDB ID: 4BCP) were obtained to explain the observed preference (Figure 12), revealing that 45 shares a similar binding conformation in both kinases. However, due to the steric hindrance between the 1,4-diazepane moiety of 45 and Lys89 in CDK2, the binding process of 45 and CDK2 produces an “inward” or “outward” conformation, which is not observed in the CDK9, indicating that the CDK2 binding pocket is too crowded for 45. Although 45 has similar modes of action with CDK9 and CDK2, there are still some obvious differences. On the one hand, the binding of 45 to CDK9 induces the lowering of the glycine-rich loop into the ATP-binding site, which does not occur in CDK2. On the other hand, different from the apo structure of CDK9, the backbone of the hinge region in CDK9 shifts from the position where 45 is located to accommodate the binding of 45, which contributes to the formation of the hydrogen bond between C2-NH of the pyrimidine and Cys106 at an optimal length of 2.8 Å. Both differences suggest that compared to CDK2, the CDK9 protein has a more flexible ATP-binding pocket to accommodate the binding of 45.(103)
    While compound 45 had a high selectivity over most CDKs, with an IC50 value of 92 nM for CDK7.(103) In order to discover a CDK9 inhibitor with higher selectivity than 45, Liu et al. performed the docking studies between 45 and CDK7/9 to find the motivation to explore the selectivity between CDK7 and CDK9.(29) The analysis of binding modes indicated that the flexibility of the CDK9 P-loop and the shallow hydrophobic pocket formed by the Gly112 and His108 residues may be exploited to enhance the preference for CDK9 over CDK7. Furthermore, they postulated that changing the CN group of 45 to the Cl atom was beneficial for the improvement of the CDK9 affinity. Based on these analyses, a detailed SAR study was conducted starting from compound 45 (Figure 13). Some biological evaluations were performed to better study the SAR, including the biochemical assay with CDK9, cellular antiproliferative potency in MV4–11, MEC-1 as well as Chinese hamster lung (CHL) cells, which was used to monitor the cytotoxicity of the inhibitors. The initial design was made to replace the CN group with a Cl atom. Compound 46 (IC50 > 10 μM) completely lost the potency for CDK9, while the activity of compounds 47 and 48 was restored (IC50 = 0.56 and 0.24 μM, respectively). However, all of them showed no inhibitory activity in tumor cells. Changing the phenyl to the 4-fluoro benzoyl group (49, IC50 = 2.3 μM for CDK9) gave rise to a large activity loss against CDK9 and led to a certain cytotoxicity (IC50 = 0.93 μM for CHL), suggesting that a more flexible group may be suitable at this position. Therefore, the introduction of 4-amino cyclohexyl was performed and led to compound 50, which exhibited good inhibitory activity against CDK9 (IC50 = 0.022 μM) and MV4–11 cells (IC50 = 0.55 μM). Moreover, an adequate selectivity over CHL was also observed (IC50 = 3.5 μM). Accordingly, extensive modifications at the position of 4-amino cyclohexyl were performed. Most of the acyl substitutions resulted in activity loss against CDK9 and tumor cells. However, aliphatic substitutions brought about an obvious increase in CDK9 inhibitory activity. Among them, methoxylethane substitution in 51 (IC50 = 0.002 μM) demonstrated excellent suppression of the CDK9 activity, although it showed weak inhibitory activity in tumor cells.(29)
    With the aim to improve cell antiproliferative activity of compound 51, a new round of structural optimization was performed to focus on its NH group of the aminothiazole moiety. Compound 52 (IC50 = 0.101 μM), obtained by replacing tetrahydropyran of 51 with a hydrogen atom, showed a 50-fold drop in the activity for CDK9. The hydrophobic CF3 group substitution in 53 (IC50 = 0.017 μM) restored the kinase activity, which promoted the introduction of various hydrophobic rings in the same position. Although most of them had good CDK9 activity, none of them displayed good cytotoxic activity (54, 55, 56). When the tetrahydrofuran group was introduced (57), it potently inhibited CDK9 (IC50 = 0.09 μM) and displayed good selectivity for tumor cells compared to normal cells. Furthermore, changing tetrahydrofuran to tetrahydropyran carbonitrile (58) led to excellent CDK9 inhibitory activity (IC50 = 0.002 μM), potent antiproliferative efficacy (GI50 = 0.012 and 0.037 μM for MV4–11 and MEC-1, respectively) as well as low cytotoxicity (GI50 = 1.2 μM for CHL). Compound 58 displayed the best in the biological evaluations. A selectivity higher than 1000-fold was observed for 58 when tested against CDK7 and other CDK members, including CDK1/2/3/5/8/11. Additionally, 58 exhibited outstanding selectivity for CDK in over 468 kinases/mutants in the kinase profiler panel. As for the in vitro antitumor activity, 58 could potently suppress cell proliferation in various solid tumor and leukemia cell lines with a GI50 ranging from 1 to 44 nM. Compound 58 exhibited good bioavailability in rats, mice, and dogs (F = 45.1, 45.0, and 39.1%, respectively) and completely inhibited tumor progression on day 14 of treatment with 58 (10, 20, and 30 mg/kg/day), with no obvious cytotoxicity.(29)
    A docking study of 58-CDK9 (PDB ID: 4BCG) was performed to gain a better insight into the binding mechanism (Figure 14A). The results demonstrated that there were two key hydrogen bonds formed between the aminopyridine of 58 and the hinge residue Cys106 in CDK9. In addition, another three hydrogen bonds were formed between the aminothiazole moiety and Asp167 in the activation loop, the oxygen atom of the methoxyethylamine moiety and nearby Asp109, as well as the CN group and Thr29 in the P-loop, respectively. Since compound 58 displays 1700-fold selectivity over CDK7 (IC50 = 17,200 nM), this binding mode is superimposed onto CDK7 kinase to explain the selectivity (Figure 14B). On the one hand, the hydrogen bond of the methoxyethylamine moiety does not exist due to the steric hindrance of the Val100 residue around the hinge region of CDK7, but the corresponding residue in CDK9 is Gly122, which has a smaller volume, avoiding such an impact. On the other hand, the Gly21 of CDK7 replaces the Thr29 in the CDK9 P-loop, leading to a lack of the capability to interact with the CN group of 58. Thus, the formation of five hydrogen bonds between 58 and CDK9 may contribute to its high activity and selectivity.(29)
    Compound 59, developed by Novartis, shares a similar structure with 58, where the thiazole ring in 58 is replaced with the pyridine ring of 59 (Figure 13). It can also potently inhibit CDK9 (IC50 < 0.5 nM) and displays excellent selectivity over CDK7 (IC50 > 10 μM). Compound 59 exhibited outstanding proliferation inhibitory activity in MOLT4 cells (IC50 = 9 nM). In addition, the compound was effective for the treatment of tumor, inflammation, HIV infection, and cardiac hypertrophy.(104)

    4.3.2. Selective CDK9 Inhibitors Bearing the Aminopyrimidine Scaffold

    Recently, Xu et al. reported another aminopyrimidine 61 showing significant selectivity against CDK9 over other CDKs (Figure 15A).(105) Initially, they identified compound 60 (IC50 = 184, 1211, and 27 000 nM for CDK9, CDK2, and CDK7, respectively) bearing a coumarin scaffold, which showed moderate CDK9 inhibitory activity, 7-fold and 146-fold higher selectivity over CDK2 and CDK7, respectively. According to the docking model, besides the two hydrogen bonds between the aminopyridine of compound 60 and the hinge residue Cys106 of CDK9, the coumarin group in 60 forms a hydrogen bond with Asp109 of CDK9, which account for the CDK9 activity of 60. In order to find novel and selective CDK9 inhibitors, a detailed SAR study was performed to focus on the modification of pyrimidine and coumarin in compound 60, culminating in the discovery of compound 61. Compared with 60, compound 61 showed significantly improved CDK9 activity and selectivity, with an IC50 value of 2 nM against CDK9 and 100-fold and 3000-fold higher selectivity over cell cycle CDKs (CDK1–6) and transcriptional CDKs (CDK7, CDK8, and CDK19), respectively. Xu et al. suggested that the high selectivity of compound 61 against CDK9 mainly results from the smaller volume of the Gly112/Ala111 in CDK9 than that of the residues at the same position of other CDKs,(105) which also accounts for the selectivity of compounds 21, 45, and 58. The steric hindrance of these residues in other CDKs, such as the residues Lys89/Lys88 of CDK2 and the residues Thr102/Arg101 of CDK4, prevents the interaction between the CDK protein and the bulky coumarin bearing 3-acetyl and 4-morpholino in compound 61 (Figure 15B,C). Compound 61 displayed good drug-like properties, such as potent antiproliferative activity in various tumor cells, slight hERG toxicity, and obvious tumor growth suppression in an MV4–11 mouse xenograft model. However, the PK properties of compound 61 are not good, such as the short half-life of approximately 0.23 h, which is required for further improvement.(105)

    4.3.3. Selective CDK9 Inhibitors Bearing A Nitrogen-Containing Fused Heterocycle Scaffold

    Phillips et al.(106) reported the discovery and characterization of two selective CDK9 inhibitors, namely, A-1467729 (62) and A-1592668 (63), which contains a nitrogen-containing fused heterocycle scaffold (Figure 16). Compound 62 was identified through SAR studies and shown to have a 1000-fold higher selectivity against CDK9 (IC50 = 1.2 nM) over CDK1, 2, 7, and 8, and exhibited a more potent affinity to CDK4 and CDK6 with 12-fold and 240-fold higher selectivity, respectively. At the cellular level, 62 showed potent inhibition of the phosphorylation of RNA PII (IC50 = 27.6 nM). In addition, a significant cell killing activity was observed in the H929 and MV4–11 cell lines treated with 62 (IC50 = 39 and 42 nM, respectively). However, PK studies in rats suggested a Clp of 2.1 L/h/kg via the tail vein at a concentration of 2 mg/kg 62, which was unsuitable for in vivo pharmacodynamic study. In order to reduce the clearance to within 20% of liver blood while retaining the activity against CDK9, additional structural optimization was performed. The introduction of a carboxylic acid group led to 63 with decreased clearance (Clp = 0.63 L/h/kg). Importantly, both the affinity toward CDK9 (IC50 = 2.6 nM) and selectivity over other CDKs (>100-fold) were retained. Moreover, similar cell inhibition by 63 in the Mcl-1-dependent cell lines (IC50 = 40 and 138 nM for H929 and MV4–11 cells, respectively) was also observed in the comparison with 62. As a result, 63 progressed into further studies related to CDK9 inhibition. Notably, the combination of 63 and BCL2 inhibitor venetoclax significantly induced cell apoptosis in the OCI-Ly1 199R and SC-1 199R cell lines, which developed acquired resistance to venetoclax. This combined administration could give rise to greater tumor growth inhibition than the single administration in the SU-DHL-4 xenograft model.(106)

    4.3.4. Selective CDK9 Inhibitors Bearing Various Scaffolds Claimed in Patents

    There are some selective CDK9 inhibitors whose development processes were not disclosed, especially those reported in patents. However, they also show good inhibitory activity and selectivity against CDK9 as well as novel structures. Thus, we will briefly describe them in this section (Figure 17).
    Like the macrocyclic CDK9 inhibitor 9 in a clinical study, a new macrocyclic derivative, 64, identified by Bayer exhibits potent CDK9 inhibitory activity.(107) Compound 64 is a highly potent and selective CDK9 inhibitor (IC50 = 2.1 nM), exhibiting a 500-fold higher selectivity over CDK2 (IC50 = 1,240 nM). Furthermore, changing the fluorine atom in the para position of phenyl to the meta position leading to compound 65 with a significant increase in the selectivity over CDK2 (IC50 = 7,520 nM) while maintaining the CDK9 activity (IC50 = 3.4 nM). However, 65 shows a drop in cell activity compared to 64 (IC50 = 126 and 8.2 nM in MOLM-13 cells, respectively). Compound 64 has excellent PK properties, like the maximum calculated oral bioavailability based on the stability data in rat hepatocyte and its half-life, which are as high as 93% and 6.9 h, respectively.
    Compound 66 exhibits outstanding inhibitory activity against CDK9 (IC50 = 1 nM) and high selectivity over CDK2 (IC50 = 8560 nM). Additionally, 66 shows significant antiproliferative activity in MOLM-13 and HeLa cell lines (IC50 = 46 and 38 nM, respectively).(108) The treatment with the pyrrolo-pyrimidine derivative 67 can lead to potent CDK9 inhibition (IC50 = 13 nM), which shares a similar structure with the pyrrolo-pyridine derivative 63.(109) Excellent CDK9 inhibitory activity is also observed for dipyridyl compounds 68 and 69 (IC50 = 3 and <8 nM, respectively).(110) Unfortunately, to the best of our knowledge, neither their selectivity nor their discovery process has been reported to date.
    In fact, the development of kinase inhibitors (including CDK9 inhibitors) mainly currently relies on the target-based screening, which has resulted in numerous failures in clinical studies due to the poor link between the actual state of diseases and the biological targets.(111) Thus, phenotypic drug discovery has again captured the attention of medicinal chemists.(111) In addition, new biological techniques, such as PROTACs, provide a novel and potential approach to develop CDK9 modulators.(112) Next, we will focus on the discussion of these two approaches currently used in the discovery of selective CDK9 modulators.

    4.3.5. The Application of Phenotypic Screening in the Development of CDK9 Inhibitors

    Phenotypic screening is a biological experiment involving a series of small molecules, peptides, and other substances to find agents that induce a desired phenotypic outcome (such as the inhibition of cellular proliferation), which is currently the main strategy used by medicinal chemists for the initial development of drugs.(113) Unlike targeted screening, phenotypic screening directly evaluates the ability of compounds to modulate disease-related phenotypes and identify active compounds with unknown targets and mechanisms of action. This more “holistic”, target-naive screening approach may identify initial hits that are more relevant and useful start points for medicinal chemistry optimization.(114) Some researchers believe that the knowledge of the molecular pathways and targets required for specific disease-associated phenotypes, along with the ability to use more disease-relevant cell models, can increase the chance of finding drugs with novel mechanisms of action and clinical efficacy.(113) The existing CDK inhibitors have some disadvantages, including low activity, poor physical and chemical properties, and poor selectivity. Thus, an effective phenotypic screening method may provide a novel and promising strategy to develop CDK inhibitors, including CDK9 inhibitors.(87,115)
    Epigenetic reprogramming in cancer leads to heritable changes in gene expression, such as the silencing of tumor suppressor genes.(28,116) Reversing epigenetic modifications by drugging the epigenome represents a useful tool in the field of epigenetic therapy. However, epigenetic treatment options remain limited clinically.(117) The YB5 cell-based system derived from the human colon cancer cell line, SW48, as a platform for epigenetic drug screening, was used by Zhang et al.(28) to perform high-throughput phenotypic screening of the NDL-3040 natural compound library (Figure 18), leading to an aminothiazole derivative 70 (HH1). In YB5, 70 can effectively activate the GFP gene, which is silenced by an epigenetic mechanism. However, there is no drug with aminothiazole structure among the known epigenetic drugs, facilitating the identification of CDK9 as a new regulator of gene silencing. As a result, 77 aminothiazole derivatives were designed and synthesized, and the best active compound 71 was screened using the YB5 cell-based system. The evaluations using the kinase activity assay showed that 71 was at least 22 times more selective for CDK9 (IC50 = 5 nM) over other CDK family members. Some studies suggest that the reactivation of silenced genes requires cell division to help reset the chromatin.(118) Therefore, optimizing lead compounds by GFP gene expression may be a promising strategy for identifying potent CDK9 inhibitors.
    Similarly, a high-through phenotypic screening was used to find potent inhibitors of the heat shock factor 1 (HSF1) stress pathway, which proved to be CDK9 inhibitors with high selectivity.(119) The 4,6-disubstituted pyrimidine 73 with potent inhibition of the HSF1-stress pathway exhibits a 78-fold higher selectivity for CDK9 over other CDKs (except CDK5, 43-fold). Importantly, whether it is the 4,6-disubstituted pyrimidine derivatives (72, 73, 74, 75) or other compounds with entirely different chemical structures (12 and 13), there is a good correlation between their CDK9 activity and the inhibition of the HSF1 pathway (Figure 19), indicating that CDK9 inhibition may be involved in the suppression of the HSF1-stress pathway suppression. Although the identification of compounds 71 and 73 as selective CDK9 inhibitors was not the initial purpose, their evolutions are driven through the phenotypic marker. Thus, phenotypic screening and optimization on the basis of the HSF1-stress pathway and epigenetic reprogramming might provide a new approach to develop specific CDK9 inhibitors.

    4.3.6. The Application of PROTAC Strategy in the Development of CDK9 Degraders

    PROTACs are heterobifunctional small molecules that are aimed at achieving selective degradation of the target proteins.(120) Typically, PROTACs are mainly composed of one moiety that binds the target of interest, another that binds a ubiquitin (E3) ligase, and a linker connecting these two moieties.(121) The normal physiological function of the ubiquitin-protease system is responsible for clearing mutated, denatured, or harmful proteins from cells. With the help of PROTACs, E3 ligase combined with ubiquitin-conjugating enzymes (E2) and the activated ubiquitin molecules recognizes the target proteins and ubiquitinates them, which ultimately results in the degradation of target proteins by the proteasome. (Figure 20).(121−124) Recently, the first PROTAC anticancer candidate has entered clinical trials,(125) suggesting the feasibility and efficacy of the PROTAC strategy in the development of antitumor drugs.
    Due to the high homology of the CDK family, the development of selective CDK9 inhibitors is challenging. A recent study showed that lysine residues with appropriate surface exposure have an important effect on ubiquitination and proteasomal degradation.(126) This may provide a new approach to develop small molecules selectively targeting CDKs since there are some differences in the distribution and shape of lysine residues on the surface among different CDKs.(127) Indeed, to date, many researchers have reported the identification of selective CDKs degraders, including CDK9 degraders.(127,128)
    Compound 78 is the first reported PROTAC molecule that selectively induces CDK9 cleavage. A series of aminopyrazole analogues were designed and screened for CDK activity, which led to the identification of compound 76 with selectivity for CDK5 and CDK9 over CDK2.(127) The degrader 78 was generated by conjugating compound 76 and thalidomide (77) using an alkane chain containing 4 carbon atoms (Figure 21). Western blot analysis demonstrated that compound 78 could strongly degrade CDK9 (DC50 = ∼8 μM, the value estimated from the reported data). Importantly, although the parental compound 76 displayed good inhibition against CDK5, the PROTAC 78 did not cause a clear change in the levels of CDK5, CDK2, and other kinases, such as FAK, AKT, and IKKβ, suggesting that the PROTAC molecule was a selective CDK9 degrader. Researchers believe that the selectivity of the compound might stem from the absence of a proximal lysine residue in these kinases that can be ubiquitinated.(127) In addition, a more significantly reduced level of Mcl-1 induced by degrader 78 was observed compared with parent 76.
    In 2018, our laboratory reported the discovery of wogonin-based PROTACs against CDK9, which is the first report on the application of flavonoid natural products in PROTACs targeting CDK9.(128) Among them, compound 79 can selectively degrade CDK9 in a concentration-dependent manner and potently inhibit proliferation of MCF-7 cells at low concentration (Figure 21).
    SNS-032 (13) is a potent pan-CDK inhibitor with IC50 values of 480, 38, 340, 62, and 4 nM for CDK1, CDK2, CDK5, CDK7, and CDK9, respectively, which was also used to design a degrader (80) by connecting thalidomide through a polyethylene glycol linker (Figure 21).(104,129) Compound 80 could induce rapid and specific cleavage of CDK9 in wildtype and CRBN MOLT4 cells. Although the CDK9 cleavage induced by 80 was CRBN-dependent up to a concentration of 5 μM, the levels of other CDKs were hardly changed at a concentration of 50 μM, suggesting the design of a PROTAC molecule significantly improved the preference of the parental compound 13. Additionally, in vitro antiproliferative assay of MOLT4 cells demonstrated that the CDK9 degrader 80 (IC50 = 50 nM) had a more potent inhibitory activity than parent 13 (IC50 = 173 nM).

    5. Summary and Perspectives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    CDK9 plays a vital role in transcription regulation, and the CDK9-mediated transcription of MYC and Mcl-1 is required for the growth and survival of tumor cells. Thus, the dysregulation of the CDK9 pathway is widespread in a variety of hematological malignancies, solid tumor cell lines, and other diseases, making CDK9 signaling a potential and attractive therapeutic target. An increasing number of CDK9 inhibitors have been discovered, and some have progressed into clinical studies. The pan-CDK inhibitor flavopiridol actually has good antitumor activity through the inhibition of the CDK9 pathway and has been approved by the FDA as an orphan drug for the treatment of lymphocytic leukemia. However, the use of flavopiridol may come with serious toxicities, limiting its further clinical development, which suggests the need for careful development and monitoring of novel CDK9 inhibitors with high selectivity.
    From the perspective of the CDK9 protein structure, there are some essential amino acid residues in the ATP-binding pocket of CDK9, which contribute to the activity and selectivity of CDK9. First, the interactions with the residues Cys106, Asp104, Asp164, and Thr29 in CDK9 significantly account for the kinase inhibitory activity, especially the hinge residue Cys106. Second, a less crowded environment is observed at the exit of the ATP pocket of the CDK9 protein because CDK9 Gly112/Ala111 replaces the bulkier Lys89/Lys88 in CDK2, suggesting that the ATP cavity of CDK9 may accommodate larger ligands. In addition, the shallow hydrophobic pocket, containing the His108 and Gly112 of CDK9, is replaced with the raised pocket formed by Thr96 and Val100 in CDK7, indicating that a carefully selected small hydrophobic moiety could be utilized to study the selectivity between CDK7 and CDK9. Importantly, the steric hindrance from the bulky residues at the same position was also conserved in other CDKs, such as the residues Thr104/Arg101 of CDK4, which accounted for the selectivity of several CDK9 inhibitors with high selectivity (including compounds 21, 45, 58, and 61). Accordingly, making full use of the Gly112/Ala111 residues in CDK9 may offer an opportunity to enhance the CDK9 inhibitor selectivity. Meanwhile, the formation of halogen bonds with the gatekeeper or hinge residue of CDK9, such as Phe103 and Asp104, may promote a higher selectivity and binding affinity. In addition, the whole conformation of the CDK9 protein has high plasticity and can be adapted to a ligand with a more flexible framework.(130,131)
    From the perspective of the structure of the inhibitors, we divided the structure of CDK9 inhibitors reported in recent years into six categories according to their core skeleton, namely, flavonoids, aminopyridine (aminotriazine), aminopyrimidine, fused heterocycle, bipyridine, and aminothiazole (aminopyrazole) (Figure 22). Among them, currently, inhibitors with flavonoids, aminopyridine (aminotriazine), or aminopyrimidine cores are typical CDK9 inhibitors, and most CDK9 inhibitors in clinical trials belong to these types. However, compared with CDK9 inhibitors reviewed by Sonawane et al.,(33) there is almost no CDK9 inhibitor with a new scaffold reported in the past five years. The binding models of these inhibitors to the CDK9 active site are depicted in Figure 23. The structural requirements of CDK9 inhibitors consist of three parts, namely, parts A, B, and C (Figure 23). Part A is the core scaffold of CDK9 inhibitors, which forms hydrogen bonds with the hinge residues of CDK9. This part is required to ensure the CDK9 inhibitory activity. Part C, which extends into the hydrophilic region, may serve to further improve the kinase activity, while part B adjacent to the solvent-exposed region usually serves to improve selectivity and physicochemical properties. According to the superimposition of each class of CDK9 inhibitors (Figure S1), their main differences are concentrated in parts B and C. Notably, an increasing number of studies exploring the optimization of part B have been recently reported.(80,103,106,132)
    The main drug design strategies discussed in this review are listed in Table 4. According to the list, the structure-based drug design is the main approach to develop CDK9 inhibitors, probably due to the rapid development of computer technology and the disclosure of many CDK9 structure crystals (Table 4). The ligand-binding crystallography has an extremely positive effect on the design and synthesis of novel selective CDK inhibitors. However, the most serious challenge for computer-aided technologies applied in the structure-based design strategy is that it cannot accurately simulate the complexity of biological systems,(133) which explains the poor selectivity of some CDK9 inhibitors and, to some extent, the lack of CDK9 inhibitors with novel scaffolds. Thus, some novel strategies, such as PROTAC or other approaches that do not rely or rely less on computer technology, are currently used in the development of CDK9 inhibitors or degraders. Small-molecule PROTACs targeting CDK9 can potently degrade CDK9 protein with high selectivity, while phenotypic screening may generate a specific CDK9 inhibitor with novel scaffolds. Moreover, the structural hybrid strategy is also widely used to develop CDK9 inhibitors based on known compounds.
    Table 4. Overview of the Design Strategies of CDK9 Modulators Examined in This Review
    design strategycompdaCDK9 (IC50/nM)bother CDKs or targets (IC50/nM)bref
    structure-based drug design92CDK2 (5), CDK7 (37)(88)
    16<4CDK1(370)(101)
    2119.9CDK2 (913)(87)
    2839CDK6 (41), CDK2 (>640)(91)
    325.5CDK2 (24)(95)
    582CDK7 (1720)(29)
    612CDK2 (>300)(105)
    lead optimization (SAR study)422CDK1 (25), CDK2 (180) CDK4 (90), CDK5 (210), CDK6 (210)(83)
    83 (99)
    1864CDK2 (1725), CDK5 (1093)(80)
    632.6CDK4 (162), CDK6 (101)(106)
    physicochemical properties-guided optimization284CDK1, CDK2(78)
    76other CDKs (>890), GSK3 (45–87)(98)
    171.9CDK2 (16)(79)
    structural hybridization3512CDK4 (8.8), HDAC1 (12)(96)
    3711CDK4 (148), CDK6 (145)(53)
    3912CDK4 (142)(97)
    phenotypic screening715 (28)
    7314CDK5 (610)(119)
    PROTAC strategy78 high selectivity over other CDKs(127)
    79 high selectivity over other CDKs(128)
    80 high selectivity over other CDKs(104)
    a

    Those compounds claimed in patents are not included.

    b

    The IC50 values were achieved through a kinase-based assay.

    The main objective of improving the preference of CDK9 inhibitors is to reduce or avoid their potential side effects. However, recently, dual or multiple inhibitors have been reported to possess unique advantages. Several studies have suggested that the response to mutations in downstream factors, such as in the Rb-E2F signaling pathway, contributes to the resistance of cancer cells to CDK4/6 inhibitors.(134,135) More importantly, a close association has been observed between the overexpression of CDK9 and clinical resistance to CDK4/6 inhibitors in metastatic breast cancer patients.(136) Thus, the identification of multiple inhibitors might emerge as a potential strategy to overcome resistance to signal-targeting therapeutics. In fact, the development of multitarget inhibitors against CDK9 kinase has achieved encouraging results, such as dual CDK2/9 inhibitor 32, as well as multitarget inhibitor 35 against CDK4/9 and HADC1. The CDK9 inhibitor BTX-A51 (15), which is in clinical trials for the treatment of human leukemia, also inhibits CDK7 and casein kinase 1A1.(137) Just recently, Wang et al. has disclosed the identification of a dual CDK6/9 inhibitor that significantly suppresses tumor growth in a xenograft mouse model without obvious toxicity.(91) In addition, the combination therapies have also exhibited improved anticancer activity compared to the single inhibitors of CDK9. The combination of AZD-4573 (16) with acalabrutinib, an inhibitor of bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK), resulted in enhanced antitumor activity in BTK inhibitor-sensitive in vivo models.(138) A combination of BAY-1143572 (7) with 5-fluorouracil exhibited synergistic antitumorigenic effects against esophageal adenocarcinoma.(139) Another recent study demonstrates that CDK9 inhibitors can act synergistically with bromodomain and extraterminal (BET) inhibitors in preclinical models of MLL-rearranged acute leukemia.(140) A new clinical study of venetoclax and flavopiridol in patients with relapsed/refractory AML is in the phase of recruitment,(77) indicating the potential of CDK9 inhibitors in combination therapies. These studies demonstrate that the development of multitarget inhibitors or the application of combination therapies may also be good choices to expand the clinical application of CDK9 inhibitors.
    In summary, the design of drugs and inhibitors to target CDK9 is a promising strategy for the development of antitumor drugs. More and more researchers are focusing on the discovery of CDK9 inhibitors. However, many of the found CDK9 inhibitors have not met the requirements for entry into clinical trials due to their poor physicochemical properties, high toxicity, and lack of specificity. Thus, the discovery and application of the latest effective design strategies will benefit the discovery of superior CDK9 inhibitors for clinical treatment to future successful FDA drug approvals.

      Cancer screening in the United States, 2019: A review of current American Cancer Society guidelines and current issues in cancer screening
      Smith Robert A; Andrews Kimberly S; Manassaram-Baptiste Deana; Brooks Durado; Fedewa Stacey A; Saslow Debbie; Wender Richard C
      CA: a cancer journal for clinicians (2019), 69 (3), 184-210 ISSN:.
      Each year, the American Cancer Society publishes a summary of its guidelines for early cancer detection, data and trends in cancer screening rates, and select issues related to cancer screening. In this issue of the journal, the current American Cancer Society cancer screening guidelines are summarized, and the most current data from the National Health Interview Survey are provided on the utilization of cancer screening for men and women and on the adherence of men and women to multiple recommended screening tests.
